image.altText: Two men looking at each other.

props.synopsis: Exit polls predict Keir Starmer leading Labour to a landslide win in the UK general election. The campaign was sparked by a surprise announcement from PM Rishi Sunak just six weeks ago. Follow live.

title.children: Voting closes in UK election, exit polls predict Labour landslide

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Nigel Farage’s Reform UK party damages Conservatives
Exit poll forecasts a likely Nigel Farage victory

image.altText: Senator Fatima Payman stands in front of a media pack in Parliament House to announce she's quitting the Labor Party.

props.synopsis: Senator Fatima Payman announced that she quit the Labor Party and will be running as an independent.

title.children: Labor calls for Senator Payman to quit, but in the meantime they may need her vote

image.altText: Hand of man inserting a power cord into an electric car

props.synopsis: Car buyers looking for low-emission options are choosing hybrid vehicles over fully battery-powered EVs, according to latest sales figures.

title.children: A surge in hybrid sales has surprised automakers and sounded alarm for emissions

image.altText: A man and a woman walk along a yellow sand beach and colourful umbrellas dot the shore.

props.synopsis: Sri Lanka has been rocked by a series of crises in the past two decades but locals are now urging tourists to return and enjoy its sights.

title.children: Sri Lanka suffered a catastrophic economic crisis, but is it safe to travel there?

image.altText: woman with bandaged face and tube in her mouth

props.synopsis: Newcastle woman Rebecca Ode's family is seeking answers after she lost an eye and had 14 hours of surgery for a brain haemorrhage, shattered eye socket and cheekbone after a mystery incident in Bali.

title.children: Mystery as Australian woman suffers life-changing head injuries in Bali and family fights to get her home

image.altText: A man in a suit looking on and smiling, seen from close up

props.synopsis: Britain's ruling Conservative Party appears set to be thrown out of government after 14 years, with an exit poll predicting it is facing a devastating and historic defeat.

title.children: Britain set to dump government after 14 years, exit poll predicts

image.altText: Joe Biden in black and white against a red blue gradient speaking at a podiumj

props.synopsis: As the race to become president of the United States continues to heat up, members of the Democratic party fear for their leader Joe Biden.

title.children: As Joe Biden faces increasing calls to step aside from the presidential race, here are the Democrat voices speaking out against him so far

image.altText: Cathy Freeman celebrates 400m victory

props.synopsis: NAIDOC Week celebrations officially begin on Sunday with the theme: Keep the fire burning! Blak, Loud and Proud. But can everyone celebrate?

title.children: First Nations heroes are celebrated this NAIDOC Week

image.altText: two public housing towers can be seen with the Melbourne city skyline in the background

props.synopsis: Rent for the vast majority of public housing tenants in Victoria is capped according to income, but advocates say sharp increases in market rents before rebates are applied are causing confusion and concern.

title.children: 'Something deeply wrong' as market value of Victoria's public housing properties soars

image.altText: A graphic showing a St Vincent's hospital and nib logos side by side, separated by ripped paper

props.synopsis: St Vincent's is planning to end its contract with private health insurer nib after negotiations for renewal broke down.

title.children: 'First time in 167 years': Hospital chain flags shock split from major health insurer

image.altText: Four king penguins on a wide pebbly expanse in front of icy mountains. Two are standing, one is lying down and one is grooming

props.synopsis: The marine park that includes the subantarctic Heard and McDonald Islands is set for a massive expansion, with the federal government planning to protect an extra 300,000 square kilometres of ocean.

title.children: Government flags massive expansion of Antarctic marine park for 'untouched' Heard and McDonald Islands

image.altText: A composite image with a photo of Donald Trump, a gorilla statue and a female athlete kayaking

props.synopsis: Think you've kept a keen eye on the news cycle this week? Test yourself!

title.children: Weekly news quiz: A Trump ruling, Garry the missing gorilla and an Olympic feat

image.altText: A blonde woman in a boat captains uniform smiles with her arms crossed

props.synopsis: All aboard with the strong-willed captain of Below Deck: Mediterranean for a rapid-fire round of questions, silly and serious.

title.children: Captain Sandy Yawn on the moments you don't get to see on Below Deck: Mediterranean

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

props.synopsis: UK financial markets rallied overnight as investors await the results of the general election, while Wall Street was closed for the Independence Day public holiday in the US. Follow live.

title.children: UK markets rally ahead of election results, ASX to dip as Wall Street goes offline for Independence Day

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Need a refresher on what happened in the finance world yesterday?
A lower start likely for the ASX as UK markets rise on election expectations

image.altText: A phot of an Indigenous man looking directly at the camera with Indigenous mural in background.

props.synopsis: With election day just months away in the Northern Territory, a prominent Indigenous leader is calling on politicians — and the media — to change the narrative around Aboriginal people.

title.children: As the NT election looms, this Alice Springs leader fears a disturbing narrative is spreading

image.altText: A sign for a police station in Tasmania.

props.synopsis: A former Tasmanian cop repeatedly groomed boys over his decades-long career. A report into Paul Reynolds has outlined how he used his standing in the community to do it.

title.children: 'The funniest bloke I've ever met': How paedophile police officer Paul Reynolds groomed an entire community

image.altText: A girl sitting cross-legged looking at her phone with a worried look on her face; and her forehead in the palm of her hand

props.synopsis: Experts think exposure to traumatic content on social media, such as uncensored images coming out of the Middle East, can give some people PTSD. So what signs should you look out for, and how can you protect yourself?

title.children: When doomscrolling could lead to 'vicarious trauma'

image.altText: an Aboriginal woman with short grey hair wearing glasses

props.synopsis: It's this history Florence Onus will share at Queensland's truth-telling inquiry when community sessions begin next month. WARNING: This story contains images of Indigenous people who have died, which have been provided by family for the purpose of truth-telling and healing.

title.children: 'Mugshots' before they were forced off Country are the only photos of Florence's grandparents

image.altText: Greg Messer and Nicola Wellings in the water at Hervey Bay's Torquay Beach

props.synopsis: Greg Messer collapsed and clinically died — for more than 15 minutes — after a cardiac arrest in October 2020 following a triathlon swim,  but the actions of those nearby who knew CPR saved his life.

title.children: Triathlete, 75, would have been a victim of Australia's 'silent killer' if not for quick-thinking strangers

image.altText: A lake which has iced over. The sun shines brightly overhead.

props.synopsis: The abnormal pressure is having a significant impact on the nation's weather, including extreme low overnight temperatures over south-east states and a lengthy stretch of showery days along the eastern seaboard.

title.children: Australia's highest air pressure on record observed as monster high engulfs the nation

image.altText: sheep pic

props.synopsis: In an interview with Stateline WA, Murray Watt insists the federal government's $107 million transition package was "significant", but says discussions will continue with the state government to determine what is needed.

title.children: Federal minister keeps door open on increasing $107 million support package after live sheep export ban

props.synopsis: The local fallout from the Middle East war is signalling that Australian multiculturalism has moved into a new, more challenging phase, fraying its fibre. Even when it finally ends, the divisions and wounds will not be healed easily or soon.

title.children: Fatima Payman has joined the club of 'Labor rats' and taken a piece of modern, diverse Australia to the crossbench

image.altText: A close-up shot of a person's hands holding a set of silver house keys.

props.synopsis: The Canberra couple were awarded $1,500 in non-economic damages after a real estate agent entered their bedroom while the wife was in bed asleep with her infant son.

title.children: Canberra couple awarded damages after wife awoken by a real estate agent in her bedroom conducting an inspection

image.altText: outside view of federal court in australia

props.synopsis: Leith Dawes takes the office of the ACT's Work Health and Safety Commissioner to the Federal Circuit Court, alleging a breach of general workplace protections.

title.children: Former WorkSafe ACT employee asks for $400,000 in compensation, arguing he was unfairly sacked

image.altText: A composite image of a man and a sword next to a ruler

props.synopsis: Anthony Bray, 48, from Nuneaton, east of Birmingham, says he bought the 20 centimetre replica sword online as a fidget toy.

title.children: British man carrying Legend of Zelda sword in public as a fidget toy faces jail time

image.altText: A sprint finish at the Tour de France, with cyclists across the road, the rider on the far right will be the winner.

props.synopsis: A dramatic conclusion at the Tour de France sees a sprint contender relegated and the stage win in Dijon decided by a photo finish.

title.children: Tour de France stage decided by a photo finish, relegation

image.altText: A close up of Lidia speaking.

props.synopsis: A Darwin barrister has raised the alarm on the NT's community legal sector, saying it is 'collapsing', and will only get worse if a nation-wide funding shortfall for community legal centres isn't filled.

title.children: Thorpe calls on Albanese government to be 'fair-dinkum' on family violence, and fix community legal sector funding deficit

image.altText: Protesters hold up placards denouncing domestic violence.

props.synopsis: The ABC was granted access to Adelaide's specialist Family Violence Court for one day of hearings, where people from all walks of life can be the accused, or the victim of family violence.

title.children: South Australia's domestic violence crisis laid bare as submissions open for royal commission

image.altText: Two buildings: one labelled 'Barnes & Noble', the other labelled 'Dick's'.

props.synopsis: 68-year-old Patricia McKay was struck and killed by a white sedan during a botched robbery attempt at Fashion Island mall, Newport Beach.

title.children: Police identify tourist killed at South California mall as wife of prominent New Zealand businessman Doug McKay

image.altText: A woman stands with three people in front of a helicopter - two are in police and paramedic uniforms.

props.synopsis: As Bron stood atop a ridge, trying to find her way back to the Larapinta Trail, all she could think about was the Victorian hiker whose body was retrieved from the same track only a month before.

title.children: Hiker with only half a cup of water rescued from remote track where man was found dead a month ago

image.altText: A young woman wearing grey dress over black skivvy stands in front of a house, smiling with a mug in her hands

props.synopsis: Australian homes are notoriously cold in winter — draughty, with poor insulation, thin glass and inadequate heating. But there's a growing movement of people retrofitting their homes to make them cheaper to run and more comfortable year-round, while also reducing emissions.

title.children: Got an old, cold house like Laine's? Here are seven ways to make it warmer and cheaper
